results.description:
This event is proudly brought to you by Soccer Beyond!

Learn more on SoccerBeyond.com or Facebook.com/SoccerBeyond.

Details - Fun, interactive, effective.

60min. This is a Coed Soccer Lesson covering soccer techniques for passing, receiving, dribbling, turning, and much more. 

Please bring your own ball. Sneakers, running and turf shoes are fine. Bring some water or sports drink and maybe sun blocker. Please note our Waiver of Liability and 24hr Cancellation Policy below. More details follow.


Rain or Shine - If you don't hear from us, the session is on!

Our sessions will be held as scheduled if weather allows. Thunder or snow and ice are among the reasons for sessions to be canceled/ moved. BUT: Don't make assumptions - you will always get notified if a class is canceled/ moved. As the weather changes quickly in NYC, occasionally we may make the final decision about 90min prior to session start. If you don't hear from us, the session is on!

Cancelled/ Moved Sessions - You will always get notified!

Every time we have to cancel a session, if possible, we move it to the same day and time of the following week. In this case, all players keep their spots. Please email us prior to the rescheduled event, if you can't make and wish a refund or credit. The 24 hours cancellation policy applies. You will always get notified if a class is canceled/ moved.

Requesting a Refund

To request a refund 1) change your status to "not going" and 2) send us a note with the Paypal transaction number related to the payment for the respective session. Refunds are processed once a week - please be patient.


24 Hours Cancellation Policy

A full refund/ credit will be given if cancellation is received at least 24 hours prior to lesson start. Full payment is required thereafter. Our cancellation policy also applies to package holders.


Waiver of Liability and Hold Harmless Agreement

By RSVP'ing for this event you certify that you are physically fit such as you are able to participate in this program. You therewith voluntarily release CoachFrankNYC/ Soccer Beyond, LLC from any and all liability resulting from or arising out of your participation and/ or receipt of instruction. You read and agree to the WAIVER OF LIABILITY AND HOLD HARMLESS AGREEMENT to be found on SoccerBeyond.com/pages/waiver.

Please let us know if you have any questions or suggestions.

Coach Frank  
M. [masked]

SoccerBeyond.com
[masked]


Feel free to like us on http://www.facebook.com/SoccerBeyond.

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there on time so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER :)

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. You will not be allowed to play with cleats.

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and ground kick-ins and pop-up goals.

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 102nd street and Amsterdam Ave. The entrance gate is located on west101st and Amsterdam ave. 

Directions: 1 train to 103rd St. Also, B or D trains to 103rd St stop

Check the MTA's website for any service changes: www.mta.info

Time: Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a full refund. This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:
If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, you will be sent an automated e-mail letting you know that a spot has just openned :). If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text me or call me at[masked]-5725.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
http://nysec.org/sites/default/files/styles/medium/public/images/Bob%20Berson.jpg?itok=S4vEDn9K Robert J. Berson, Ed.D., Ph.D. 

Dick Van Deusen presides 

Human beings play, as do so many of our fellow creatures on this earth we share. What is“play”? What makes us—and other animals—play? What is play for, and is there any relationship of play and ethics? It is not oxymoronic to take play seriously, as it is a universal human phenomenon — but at the same time, it can be fun!

Robert J. Berson, Ed.D., Ph.D. is Leader of the Ethical Society of Northern Westchester and a clinical psychologist with a practice in Manhattan. He is a graduate of the Childrens Sunday Assembly of the Riverdale-Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture and of the Ethical Culture Fieldston School. He graduated from Haverford College and earned graduate degrees from Harvard University, Bank Street College of Education, Teachers College, and the City University of New York. He taught in the Ethics Department at Fieldston, has worked in the counseling services of several area colleges and universities, and supervises graduate students in clinical and counseling psychology doctoral programs. 

Entry to our 100-year-old building and meeting rooms is available for most wheelchair users with prior arrangements. Please call ahead  [masked] x 107) for setup of our portable system and plan to arrive one hour before start time.

<a>
</a>

results.description:
This run will be beginner-friendly, but we welcome runners at all levels. We will be running anywhere from 2 - 6ish miles depending on what everyone is looking to do. 

The main starting point will be at Columbus Circle by the gold statue (not the silver unisphere).

Here are some options:

Advanced: 
6 miles: Lots of hills. Run along the full outer loop of the park. The hills are more challenging if you run counter-clockwise. 

Intermediate: 
~5 miles: Run along the outer loop but cut across the 102nd st traverse.  You'll skip the infamous Harlem hill.

Beginner: 
1.7 miles: Run around the lower loop. Cut across the 72st traverse and hang a left again once you hit the west side, end back at Columbus Circle.

If possible we will break into pace groups, but either way lets meet back at the USS Maine Monument around 11-11:15am.

Where do I leave my stuff?
The New York Running Company at the Time Warner Center (located on the 2nd floor) has open bins, and lockers behind the cash register. To use the lockers, you must bring your own lock. They also have changing rooms. These services are free. The New York Running Company opens at 11am on Sunday.

What time does the run actually start? 
Plan on arriving at 11am, but we won't start running until about 11:15am in case people need to change or drop off their stuff at the NY Running Company. We will not wait longer than 11:15am. 


After the run once everyone is together again, we can grab some food nearby. Our goto place is typically Cosmic Diner on 52nd and 8th ave. Hot chocolate, coffee, pancakes? Mmmm.. If anyone wants to suggest a different place that is close by, we're flexible.


Call/text Henry at (646)[masked] if you have any questions or are having trouble finding us.

Dig deep and drag yourself out to go for a run! You'll be glad you did!

** only RSVP 'No' if you were previously a 'Yes'.

results.description:
EVENT TYPE: Tour

ADMISSION PRICE: $1 Pay as you wish

PLEASE NOTE: Metropolitan museum of art is very close by.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oCr0ndB4_hk

DESCRIPTION:

Welcome to The Frick Collection. Internationally recognized as a premier museum and research center, the Frick is known for its distinguished Old Master paintings and outstanding examples of European sculpture and decorative arts.

The collection was assembled by the Pittsburgh industrialist Henry Clay Frick (1849–1919) and is housed in his former residence on Fifth Avenue. One of New York City’s few remaining Gilded Age mansions, it provides a tranquil environment for visitors to experience masterpieces by artists such as Bellini, Rembrandt, Vermeer, Gainsborough, Goya, and Whistler. The museum opened in 1935 and has continued to acquire works of art since Mr. Frick’s death.

Adjacent to the museum is the Frick Art Reference Library, founded in 1920 by Helen Clay Frick as a memorial to her father. Today it is one of the leading institutions for research in the fields of art history and collecting.

Along with special exhibitions and an acclaimed concert series, the Frick offers a wide range of lectures, symposia, and education programs that foster a deeper appreciation of its permanent collection.

http://enfilade18thc.files.wordpress.com/2014/06/thumb-php.jpeg?w=720

ATTRACTIONS:

• West Gallery

• Garden Court


• Backyard

• East Gallery

• Grand Staircase

REFERENCE LINK:

http://www.yelp.com/biz/frick-collection-new-york

http://www.frick.org/visit

DISCLAIMER:

http://www.meetup.com/NYCAsianMeetup/pages/Disclaimer

END

My cell[masked] AUTHOR'S NOTE: THIS ROUTE SHOULD NOT BE CONFUSED WITH THE APPALACHIAN TRAIL APPROACH FROM THE SOUTH THAT BEGINS ON ROUTE 23 NEAR THE ENTRANCE TO HIGH POINT STATE PARK.

From NY: Take I-84 Exit 2 and proceed south on County Route 55 (AKA Mountain Road). This road crosses into New Jersey approximately 3.3 miles from the Interstate and becomes Route 519 but keeps the Mountain Road moniker. The Appalachian Trail crosses the road approximately 2/10 of a mile into New Jersey. Park on the shoulder of the road.

From NJ: The State Route 23/County Route 519 split is located approximately 1 mile southeast of the entrance to High Point State Park. From this point, follow Mountain Road (County Route 519) north for 2.3 miles to the Appalachian Trail crossing. Park on the shoulder of the road.

results.description:
Head and Heart: Finding the Balance

Speaker: Jone Johnson Lewis, Leader, Riverdale-Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture

Details: Are you more the emotional type or more analytical? What would it mean for our head and heart to be listening to each other more? Leader Jone Johnson Lewis will draw on science about the brain’s specialized hemispheres, and practical philosophy — that branch of philosophy that asks “How Shall We Live?” — in looking at the need to integrate these functions of our mind, to improve our ability to make choices for the common good.

*If you're interested in this topic, we also have a monthly discussion and study group for mind/brain issues and ethics: Your Brain on Ethics.

About the Speaker: Jone Johnson Lewis is the new clergy Leader at the Riverdale-Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture. Jone has been an Ethical Culture Leader since 1991, serving Ethical Societies in Chicago, Northern Virginia and Brooklyn. She's currently the President of the National Council of Leaders and a member of the American Ethical Union's Membership Committee.


Sunday programs are held at 11:00 AM at the Riverdale-Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture. For more information, please visit our website: <a>http://www.rysec.org </a>; 


<a href="http://www.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.rysec.org%2Fevent%2Fhead-and-heart-finding-the-balance%2F&t=Head%20and%20Heart%3A%20Finding%20the%20Balance"></a>

results.description:
Let's visit The Morgan this Sunday for the sesquicentennial Alice in Wonderland exhibit! 

Here's an excerpt from their website:

"This exhibition will bring to light the curious history of Wonderland, presenting an engaging account of the genesis, publication, and enduring appeal of Lewis Carroll's classic tale, Alice's Adventures in Wonderland. For the first time in three decades, the original manuscript will travel from the British Library in London to New York, where it will be joined by original drawings and letters, rare editions, vintage photographs, and fascinating objects—many never before exhibited.  The enchanting tale of Wonderland was first told “one golden afternoon” to Alice Liddell and her two sisters. Delighted by the fantastic world of logic and nonsense inhabited by rabbits in waistcoats and playing card gardeners, Alice begged for a written copy of her namesake's adventures under ground. Charles Lutwidge Dodgson (better known by his pen name Lewis Carroll) painstakingly wrote out the story, illustrating the original manuscript with his own pen and ink drawings. Revised and radically expanded, it appeared in 1865 as Alice's Adventures in Wonderland with the iconic illustrations of Sir John Tenniel. But Tenniel was dissatisfied with the printing quality, and the edition was suppressed almost immediately. Now, only twenty-two or twenty-three copies of the first edition are known to survive. It was quickly republished, and Tenniel's brilliant drawings (markedly different from Carroll's own) and their relationship to the text contributed to the initial and enduring success of the book. From here, the ethos of Alice and the universe of Wonderland took hold of our imagination, and—150 years later—we are still following her down the rabbit hole."

After we see the exhibit,let's check out the special tea being served in the cafe, in honor of the Mad Tea Party! Here's the link to that: http://www.themorgan.org/sites/default/files/menus/MorganCafeBrunch1.pdf

Admission and How to meet us:  General admission to The Morgan is $18, students and seniors $12.  We're meeting in the lobby at 11:30am. Look for my hand-lettered MEETUP sign near the coat check.  If you're late, ask the security guards where the Alice exhibit is. We do also have our own $1 fee to help defray the costs of maintaining this meetup group, payable to the organizer.

About The Morgan Library: 
Legendary financier J.P. Morgan was an almost obsessive collector of art and manuscripts, and today his collection is open to the public. In addition to the recently renovated new spaces for exhibitions, we ordinary folk can see his fabulous library, considered the masterpiece of Charles McKim of the famous McKim, Mead & White architectural firm (almost always, we hear of only partner Stanford White, but here we can check out what partner #1 was up to).

results.name: Morgan Library: ALICE: 150 YEARS of WONDERLAND

results.description: The Rockland Center for Spiritual Living has been in existence since 2005. Centers for Spiritual Living are an all-inclusive religion, philosophy and a way of life. Our vision is to transform lives through unity, acceptance, peace and harmony. Our mission is to be joyful, to celebrate life and to have fun... and indeed we do!
results.how_to_find_us: Find us at www.rocklandcsl.org
results.name: Sunday Celebration and Inspiration with Rev Jennifer Berkeley

group.name: Center for Spiritual Living Rockland County

results.description:
Stone Creek works for us — our July discussion in the private back room went on and on over coffee. The expanded pub-grub menu includes an $11 breakfast special, the Bloody Marys are hot, the beer is cold, and conversation sparkles, long after the plates are cleared.Come join 20 or more other freethinkers/ humanists for food, fun and well-fed conversation.

Discussion: “The Pursuit of Happiness” — How is yours going?
results.name: SHSNY Casual Sunday Brunch & Conversation

group.name: Secular Humanist Society of New York

results.description:
Stoop-shouldered and balding beneath a porkpie hat, Jonah Soloway is an old man before his time. Effectively orphaned when an SUV took his mother's life, he has retreated into a solitary world of vintage artifacts and comic books. But he longs to make a human connection—even if it means twisting the truth to get it. When he dials the number on Rose Oliveri’s 9/11 missing poster and reaches her mother, Vivian, one innocent lie leads to another, and before Jonah knows it, reality becomes uncertain even to him.

Stalked by Rose’s ghost, Jonah finds himself falling deeper into his own fabrications as he wanders a city turned surreal in terrorism’s settling dust. But when he meets Jane, an irreverent student of psychoanalysis, he’ll be forced to choose between illusion and the possibility of a true relationship. 

Both a poetic journey into the heart of post-9/11 New York and a darkly comic commentary on how we cope with loss, The Nostalgist is a striking debut novel from a masterful new author.
results.how_to_find_us: Maritime Parc may seat us at two tables if 12  people attend.  Also the time is 11:30 which is when they open.
results.name: We will be reading The Nostalgist by Griffin Hansbury (.99 on Kindle)

group.name: Jersey City Brunch Book Club meetup

results.description: Praise and Worship begins at 11:45 a.m. followed by an array of food choices on Bloomfield Avenue.  Long as we eat, I am not picky.
results.name: Praise + Worship = Brunch

results.description:
Join us for an afternoon of board games and entertainment at Manhattan's own Uncommons gaming cafe.

What is the Uncommons? The Uncommons is a board games cafe which offers a large selection of games for rental, so each weekend we meet there to play a variety of games ranging from the simple Jenga to the deviously strategic Settlers of Catan, to cooperative games like Shadows over Camelot. One thing's certain: if you have a passion for board games, and learning to play new things, the Uncommons has something for you!

Just look at all those games!


A $10 (+tax) rental fee is required for the stay, but covers any and all games for the entire afternoon until closing at 11 PM - you're even free to leave for lunch and come back. If not, the Uncommons also sells a selection of drinks, meals and snacks.

Be sure to show up on time or early, as the store occasionally fills up and we cannot guarantee a seat will be available all day long, though we will try and hold space for RSVP'd attendees.

Have any questions or requests for games to be played this weekend? Leave a comment below and we'll gladly answer.

How to get there: The nearest subway stop is West 4th St, off of the A, C, E, B, D, F and M and Christopher St/Sheridan Square on the 1 line isn't much farther. If you don't mind a walk, you can also hike down from 14th St/Union Sq (4, 5, 6) or Astor Pl (6).

Ponies guaranteed!
results.how_to_find_us: See event description.
results.name: Board Games at the Uncommons

results.description:
Bring your UAV / sUAS Drones to our regular Build and Configure get together. If you don't have one yet and are planning to buy/build soon, you are also welcome to attend.


There is plenty of space and lots of help so you can build and configure your bird(s) ready for our future Fly-Ins.

Basic tools are on hand, but bring your own specialty tools and, initially, any 'bits and pieces' you might need.  As the group grows and members come, we'll buy those 'bits and pieces' to have on hand for you..

There is a small area that can be used for testing to a height of 100ft and we'll be arranging a nearby field for higher flights soon..
results.name: Build and Configure

results.description: For those people who have just started reading the Urantia Book all the way to long time UB readers who wish to deepen their knowledge of The 5th Revelation, this new UB study group will offer you a wonderful opportunity to learn, grow and discover by reading the UB with fellow truth seekers. Twice a month, we will read the book together and gain a heightened awareness of your relationship to God and to your brothers and sisters on this planet as well as in other sectors of the Master Universe. It will reveal who we are and what our purpose really is, the true history of both our Earth and of mankind, the structure of the Master Universe and our exact location in it, the various levels and functions of beings in many other realms. It will answer questions in great detail such as how Jesus lived and what He wanted us to know and do, what life after passing from this world will be like for us all, the structure and divisions of the angels, cutting edge scientific data and much, much more! The admission for all of these study group meetings will be FREE thanks to the generous contribution of The Urantia Society of Greater New York.
results.how_to_find_us: 6th Floor, Room 608, Building Bet 5th and 6th Aves, South side of 18th St
results.name: Urantia Midtown NYC Study Group

results.description:
We offer simple meditation techniques﻿ to train our chaotic minds to become more focused and aware, so as to lead calmer, less stressed, and more fulfilling lives. A meditation practice opens our hearts and reveals us to be the caring and whole person we want to be, both to ourselves and to others.

Simple instructions are given at the beginning of each session, followed by meditation practice. We share our experiences, and we discuss how this applies to our everyday lives. The class is 1 and 1/4 hrs.
Taught by Neem Dewji, director of Yoga for Bliss and other qualified teachers.
results.name: meditation for everyone

results.description:
This is a great event where you can enjoy a baseball game, make some new friends, and maybe more!  It doesn't matter if you're a big fan or not, this will be a fun day out at the ballpark for all!

How it works / Itinerary: 

The game starts at 1:10pm, however we will have a pre-mingle from 11:45am-1pm at a local bar/pub connected to the ballpark (location announced only to those who have paid) where we will introduce you to the other attendees and give you game tickets.

Our host will greet you, and introduce you to other singles in the group. Food and drink will be available for purchase. This event is not meant to be a gender balanced or age specific. All are welcome.

You must pick up your tickets at the pre-mingle location no later than 1pm. If you arrive after 1pm you will not be able to find the group. 

Price includes a ticket to the game (500 level seating) & pre-mingle. 

Tickets are $35.75 on/bef 7/16, $45.75 after - http://dljparty.ticketleap.com/metspirates/

Can I come alone? Yes, 80% attending come on their own. 

Why does your RSVP say +40? This is a multi-Meetup group event. This page only shows a small portion of the actual attendees.  40-50 members will be attending.

How do I attend? In addition to RSVP'ing you must also purchase tickets in advance.  An RSVP alone will not hold your spot and this will sell out!  Get tickets here - http://dljparty.ticketleap.com/metspirates/

results.description:
Real Self Defense is Offensive in nature. 

KravMaguy offers a true, authentic Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) training experience emphasizing hand-to-hand combat, tactical and warrior training for both men and women. The Head instructor was featured in the History Channel – The Human Weapon- a documentary about Krav Maga in Israel. His last assignment was as Tactical Security Team Leader working off the coast of East Africa. 

In this basics class you will learn to defend yourself and survive knife wielding assassins, sexual assaults or any would be attacker looking to take your life using the basic principles of kravmaguy level one system. In the end only your are responsible for your own protection. You cannot rely on others when split seconds count.

Topics covered in Level One 8 week course:
Jab cross 
Fighting Stance
Weak body spots
Hook uppercut
Basic footwork
Punching jab cross
Elbows regular
Knees
Groin strikes- knees, shin to groin, groin jab (lead leg)
Knife hands
Escape- RNC
Escape guillotine
Escape schoolyard headlock (requires matted area)
Physical requirements to pass level one:
20 pushups
35 sit ups
30 squats
Level 2 training prep


check out this youtube video to see kravmaguy knife defense in action, these techniques are used by murderers and terrorists to kill countless innocents and knowing these basic defenses can save your life and the ones you love

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BbzLjAUlyzU

the eye rake to elbow to the spine: a kravmaguy classic:
results.how_to_find_us: Price per class is $25.00 (first class is free, but you must RSVP).Tell the receptionist you are here for Krav Maga and turn right to the Martial arts room- cant miss us.
results.name: Krav Maga Level One

results.description:
The purpose of this meet-up is to bring local amateur brass instrument players -- trumpet, cornet, french horn, tuba, euphonium, baritone, trombone -- together to play classical, standards, and other arrangements musically as an ensemble. We are seeking to increase our musicianship and experience in group playing.

We meet in a professional studio space around Herald Square, Manhattan. Just bring your instrument! Sheet music is supplied in advance (print-your-own) on this website under More--->Files.

Your $5 admission covers (1) MeetUp.com fees, (2) studio rental, and (3) sheet music acquisition.


Music for Sunday, Aug. 16:

New Works:

Celtic Brass (If you are a trumpet, please print ALL Bb parts (incl. "Bb trombone" and "Bb Bass". Trombone/C insts: print bass clef trombone AND tuba parts!)


Repertory:

Brass Sextet (Glass)
I'll Build a Stairway to Paradise (Gershwin)
Tiger Rag (arr. Gale)
Sonata Pian' e Forte (Gabrielli)
Voluntary on Old 100th (Purcell)
Judas Maccabeus Suite (Handel)
Gavotte (Bach) - Canadian Brass arr.
Prayer/Abendsegen (Humperdinck) - Canadian Brass arr.


YouTube links:
Abendsegen: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eMJ3p5nbhoo
Brass Sextet: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qoBHituwVYs
Gavotte (for wind quintet): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zsjgg1KT5dc
Gavotte (original solo cello): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3hbYoIs-euU
Handel: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L4xisiSWXWU
I'll Build a Stairway: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7ZgXxJ6Ameg
(hear Liza Minelli sing it: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BZ5nrIgHKZw )
Sonata Pian' e Forte https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rQeikHMQGOM
Tiger Rag (similar arrangement) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VgDYGhT8lGo
Voluntary Old 100th: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Eph7Izv4F6g


Bring: your instrument, printed sheet music parts, $5 cash, a positive attitude

Do not bring: music stand, guests, food, pets, bad vibes

Arrive on time, ready to play! It is essential that you be respectful of the space and your fellow players.
results.name: Full Brass Ensemble

results.description:
PHOTOGRAPHERS!

Join us at Adorama Sunday August 16th for one of two FREE seminars on pin up photography!

Founder Brandon Herman will introduce some of the best practices for creating retro-inspired images in studio environments as well as out in the field. Drawing upon 9 years of experience producing group photoshoots, this session will discuss lighting, working with models, set construction, shooting, image editing, and more.  The lovely model Pearls Daily will be there to help us demonstrate various shooting techniques.  It will be a fun and fast presentation with time for a Q & A!

This seminar will be two (2) sessions of ninety (90) minutes each.

Session 1 runs 12-1:30 PM, and session 2 runs 2- 3:30 PM.

Register on the Adorama website here:


http://www.adorama.com/alc/browse/pages/seminar-modern-pinups-studio-and-location


You must register at the above link. ^^^ Your RSVP here means nothing, although we're happy to see your interest!

Adorama is located at 42 West 18th Street, NYC. It's just a short walk from Union Square or the 6th Avenue - 14th Street subway station.

model Pearls Daily shot by Brandon Herman

results.description:
This form is the first self-defense form or training drill that we learn in the Erle Montaigue’s Fajing Chuan system. It is a form that covers every possible defense and counter attack we might find in a real confrontation, and trains our subconscious to react properly in such situations. It also strengthens our muscles, sinews and joints in order to be healthy to defend our life. The series of intricate and specific movements also trains the practitioner in the usage of the correct muscles to strike and to perform fajing (explosive energy). Needless to say, like any other training method in the system, it also improves our self-healing and our ability to heal others, by combining forcefully our mind’s intent with our qi, and teach them how to work together. This is a form that was developed by Yang Shouzhong, Yang Cheng-fu’s eldest son, in order to bring back the Yang energy element stripped in the simplifications made by his father to the original form. 

Note:

These series of free classes are intended to show the both sides of the original Yang style: the ‘softer’ and internal, and the ‘harder/martial’ and external. It will also elucidate the link between the both sides of the same coin - fajing. On one side, we train it slowly, in order to train the subconscious on how to recover that natural expression of energy, and to impart it with some sophistication that makes it more suitable for our higher-goals: self-healing and medical (healing others) work. On the other, we train on how to use it for self-defense purposes, and on how it can help give us the best chance of survival when our life is in true danger.

results.description:
A small, supportive group for artists of all types to come together and talk about and share their creative projects in a fun, non-judgmental environment. New members welcome. (Each person pays $1 cash at the meetings, just to help offset the costs of having the group hosted here on MeetUp.com.)

Every week, we meet from 12:00 pm to 2:00 pm. Usually, we work through Julia Cameron's creativity building techniques (for example those in The Artist's Way and The Prosperous Heart). We start each session discussing the current week's activity (morning pages, artist's dates, synchronicities, creative endeavors, etc) and then participate in an agreed upon exercise/task (bring paper and pen please).


Normally, on the third Sunday of the month, we share our artistic projects in a kind of "Show & Tell" so that we can get to know each other's work and support it. Not mandatory - only for those who wish to share or present their work.


This is a very creative and supportive small group. Please join us.
results.name: The Artist's Way

results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.


WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...


1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play anywhere in NYC, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated


9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved


Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.

HOW TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be responsible to attend. You can pay in cash on the courts with Terry on court #5.

WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>

results.description:
Updated April 18th, 2015

This is one of three sites/listserves that promotes weekly games that have been going on for many many years. Stall counts are used on occasion, cleats are optional, boundaries are flexible, and all skill levels are welcome!

There are two ways to stay in touch outside of Meetup.com:

- Follow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/nycultimate 
- Like us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/nycultimate

SPRING/SUMMER (Mar - Aug)

As the city warms up we play four times a week. We use Riverside Park on Tuesdays/Thursdays and Morningside Park for the weekend games.

There are four days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Morningside Park (110th and Manhattan Ave) 
- Sundays at 12pm, Morningside Park (110th and Manhattan Ave) 
- Tuesdays at 6pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!) 
- Thursdays at 6pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!)

Damien 
[masked]


MORNINGSIDE DETAILS

The Morningside location is at the corner of 110th Street and Manhattan Avenue. The best way to get there is to take the B or C local to 110th Street. You can also take the 1 train to 110th street at Broadway and then walk East. We will play at the South end of the baseball field parallel to 110th street so that we're not in the way of the baseball games. Riverside will be our backup if for some reason we need to change locations.

RIVERSIDE DETAILS

The Riverside location is all the way West just off the water between 102nd and 108th Streets. You can only enter the park at 103rd and 108th. The best way to get there is to take the 1 local to 103rd Street. Walk West until you see an entrance that takes you down to the fields through the park. After walking down the steps from the street, you will see a path that goes left and another that goes right. Walk down the left path until you see a stone wall and stairs that go down to the fields. From South to North there will be one small soccer field surrounded by a track (red 'A' on map), another field with two softball fields (closer to 103rd/104th st) and another that is a giant soccer field (closer to 106th st). After walking down the steps, you will see the small Soccer field on your left. Start from this Southern-most field and walk North on the path to find our game. If you see no one, the meeting spot is the South side of the large soccer field. This spot is identified on the map below, a small square with little dots around it. On days when we can't find space at Riverside, we will move the game to Morningside Park (West 110th St and Manhattan Ave).

results.description:
Can you add an hour or two of community organizing to your summer schedule? Can you help survey ordinary people and ask them about the impact of diagnosis and our current mental health system on their lives? If so, please join me and many others who will be out in Harlem. See the invitation below. At the bottom is a link to a Psychology Today  blog where you can learn more about this campaign and also a link to take the survey. 

Community Organizing at Harlem Day
Ordinary People Never Get Asked. Until Now!
How do YOU think about mental health, emotional distress and psychiatric diagnosis? 

Volunteer to survey NY residents at one of the largest outdoor fairs. 
All it takes is an hour or two or more.

Harlem Week is one of the most diverse multicultural celebrations in NYC offering educational and heath related activities as well as food, crafts, an entire games section for children and lots of music and entertainment. And . . . we will be there!

Every year the Social Therapy Group and the East Side Institute speak to hundreds of people who come out to Harlem Week (and in Sept to Atlantic Antic). This year we are continuing to survey the community with the Emotional Distress and Mental Health Diagnoses Survey which solicits opinions of people - ordinary people who never get asked - how they think about mental health, emotional distress and psychiatric diagnosis. And this summer, Dr. Lois Holzman, director of the East Side Institute and a member of the Global Summit on Diagnostic Alternatives, will be sharing the results of this survey with thought leaders and policy makers in psychology and education nationally and internationally, including at the upcoming American Psychological Association (APA) Convention in Toronto. 

We plan to reach hundreds more over the next few months. Help us bring ordinary people into the dialogue and give them a voice in determining our emotional lives and mental health. 

See blog on Psychology Today
How Do You Think About Emotional Distress? Take the Survey!
by Dr. Lois Holzman, Director, East Side Institute
results.how_to_find_us: I will get an email out with exact location once it's been assigned
results.name: Community Organizing in Harlem

results.description:
Organizers of the NY Pin Up Club (www.NYPinUpClub.com) will introduce some best practices for creating retro-inspired images in studio environments as well as out in the field!  Drawing upon 9 years of producing group photoshoots, this session will discuss lighting, working with models, set construction, shooting, image editing, and more.  A beautiful model will be there to help us demonstrate various shooting techniques.  It will be a fun and fast presentation with time for a Q & A!


This seminar will be two (2) sessions of ninety (90) minutes each

Adorama is located at 42 West 18th Street, NYC. We're just a short walk from Union Square or the 6th Avenue - 14th Street subway station.

Biography:

http://www.adorama.com/alc/sites/default/files/styles/bio_image/public/Brandon_HEAD.jpg?itok=3XcqL5lo

The NY Pin Up Club has been going strong for over 9 years, and currently boasts well over 4,000 members.  We produce a group photoshoot almost every month, all inspired by the retro charm of pin ups of the 1930s, 40s, and 50s.  We book the studio or location, find the models, set up the lights, build the sets, and organize the entire day.  We've done shoots with vintage WW II planes, at a trolley museum, and at a boxing gym....we've even done two-day weekend shoots in sunny Wildwood, NJ.  We leverage the power of a large group to secure production elements that would be prohibitive for any one person to lock down.  Photographers sign up via our website and walk into a completely produced shoot...the only thing missing is YOUR unique style and creativity!  We work hard to make sure that everyone is getting one-of-a-kind images different from all the other photographers at the shoot!  Join us!  www.NYPinUpClub.com
results.name: SEMINAR: Modern Pinups: In the Studio and On Location

results.description:
Join us for a Hiking & Swimming Party!! August 16th (Sun) 

Do ya love nature? Feel like taking a hike or jump in the lake? Now, you can do both!! Join the JOC as we hike in Harriman State Park followed by a swim in Lake Welch!

Hike Details: http://www.nynjtc.org/hike/long-path-long-mountain-summit-harriman-state-park

Swim Details: http://www.nysparks.com/parks/134/details.aspx 

Schedule: (Meet Up @ 12PM) 


We will meet in the parking lot at 12PM to sign in and expect to hit the trails shortly thereafter. Give yourselves some extra time in case you get stuck in traffic. The hike should take about 2-3 hours. We will hike at a relaxed pace and enjoy the panoramic views along the way. We will hit the water after the hike in Lake Welch to cool off (BEACH PARTY!) 

How much does it cost?
The hike is FREE but there may be a nominal parking fee at the beach. 

Rideshare: 


We will send out a spreadsheet as soon as we close registration with a list of drivers and their contact details to the registered attendees. Passengers are expected to each reimburse their driver $15 for gas, tolls, and wear & tear… 

Packing List: 


Lots of water for the hike (min 3 liters of water) and Swimwear for the beach, lunch/snacks, hiking boots (or sneakers with good support for hiking), comfortable clothing that can get dirty, sun tan lotion, bug spray, and 15 dollars to reimburse your driver (if you are a rider), camera, binoculars, beach ball and a happy face! 

Oh my, I’d love to Hike & Swim! How do I sign up???
Signup through this meetup group and fill out the registration questions so we can keep you in the loop. 


See ya all on the trails (and in the water!!) 

Marvin & Moshe

results.description:
Note: Only RSVP if you are planning to show up.

First Timers, READ details before you RSVP. 

Where: The Cliffs at LIC, [masked]th Drive, Long Island City, NY

When: We usually climb between 1:00pm and 4:00 pm. There is no strict start time and the organizer(s) tries their best to be there around 1:00pm. We will pair off around 1.15ish and start climbing. 

Transportation: Subway: E, M trains to 23rd St-Ely Ave (1/2 block from gym) 7, G train to Court Square (2 blocks from gym)* N, Q train to Queens Borough Plaza (10min walk) *Walk to the E & M track for those bad weather days 

Metro North & LIRR: From Grand Central take 7 train 3 stops From Penn Station take Uptown E train to Court Square

Cost/Discount: Monthly membership of $105 (the $99 Initiation Fee is waived if you sign up during the meet up). Just mention "Rock & Ice" at the front desk in order to receive your discount. Gear rental is free for first-timers ONLY  (first time visit to the facility). Regular gear  pricing info can be found here: http://thecliffsclimbing.com/lic/climbing/pricing/
For Beginners, Climbing 101 class is offered 50% Off if you do it the same day as the meet up and has to be scheduled in advance with them.</a>

How to meet us:  After you checked-in, to the right of the front desk there's a sitting area.If you see a group of people in there that's probably us come and say hi. If you are running late or can't find the group leave a message in the Comments section.  Food/drinks apres-climb at John Brown Smokehouse next door (or whichever resto the group decides). Even if you only want to have a beer with us, that is also acceptable :)

Notice to Beginners: If you have never climbed before, we encourage you to take the Climbing 101 class there before attending the meetup. We get a discounted price of $25 for the class (that's 50% Off original price if you do it the same day as the meet up and has to be scheduled in advance with them). This will also cover your day pass + gear for the day. Unfortunately we can't teach you how to belay or let you try to belay at the gym if you are not belay certified yet. We leave the teaching to the experts.  Check out Cliff's website for more details.  What to wear - comfortable clothes (think yoga).

Notice to newcomers: You need to pass a belay certification. If you had belayed before, the test takes couple of minutes. If you need a refresher, a test partner or belay partner, please see feel free to see me. Here is the link to The Cliffs LIC <a href="http://thecliffsclimbing.com/lic/">http://thecliffsclimbing.com/lic/

If you decide to stick with the sport, please peruse our message boards for good deals on climbing shoes and other gear.  Also if you find this group invaluable, please donate and pay your voluntary membership due ;) the Organizers will love you more ;)
results.name: Weekend Climbing at the Cliffs LIC

results.description:
There is always high demand for figure sessions, but I don't have the time to organize more. So my friend (artist extraordinaire) Simon has offered to host some weekly sessions. These events won't impact the regular schedule of the group; they're additional. Hope to see you there! - Jesse

Join us for Saturday figure sketching, at a beautiful space conveniently located in Union Square! We'll be in Suite 505.

Unlike our outdoor Meetups, this one costs money so we can pay for the space and models. It's $15 per person, pay at the door. These sessions tend to be in high demand, so only RSVP if you are pretty sure you will attend! If not, please open the spot for someone else.

Any problems on the day of the event, Simon can be reached at [masked]. 

Looking forward to sketching with you!


What makes our Meetups different from other art groups and classes? There's no instruction, but we like to share our work, and chat and be inspired. Share tips and learn from people in a casual environment where all levels of artists are welcome! Don't be shy to ask anyone anything!


• We sketch for a bit, and then take a break and share our drawings. Then we sketch some more, etc.

• Feel free to bring any media you like to work with - pens, pencil, watercolor, pastel, small sketchbook or large paper, iPad, whatever suits you.

• We hand out nametags so everyone can meet one another!

• We take photos (not of the model) to share on the site later. Bring your camera!

• The event will last three hours.

• Everyone at all skill levels is welcome!

How does the Wait List work? If the event is full, rsvp to be added to the Wait List. If someone from the regular list cancels, the first person on the Wait List is automatically bumped up to the attending list.


Please note that if you add a comment below it will spam everyone with an email, so please use your judgement.

results.description:
Join us for three hours of figure drawing in the heart of Union Square.

This session is open to sketchers of all levels.


What makes our sessions different? 

• We work in a large, clean, well-lit space. 

• Sketchers can concentrate because our room is quiet while the model is posing.

• (Latecomers can be seated at a break.)


• Every hour we take a break to look each others drawings (if you choose to put yours out.) This is a nonjudgmental and very valuable part of the session. 

• This is a three hour drawing session to work from a live (nude) model.  


• We start with 5 minute poses and work up to 20 minute poses by the end of the session. We take a 5 minute break every 20 minutes. 

• There are seats for everyone tables and several light weight easels. 


• Access to a sink is available for watercolor artist.

• Bring your own materials (no oil or acrylic paint and no sprays please.)

As always if you have any questions please feel free to email me. I look forward to seeing you there. 

Simon

The lecture will be given by teacher Harry Miller.  Harry  studied  with  Master  Sheng  Yen  for  over  30  years.  He  was  editor  of  the  Chan  Newsletter  for  over  10  years,  is  a  frequent  contributor  to  Chan  Magazine,  and  a  lecturer  at  Chan  Meditation  Center (CMC).  He  is  a  board  member  of  Dharma  Drum  Retreat  Center  and  a  member  of  the  Dharma  Teachers  in  Training  at  CMC.  He  holds  a  B.A  in  French  and  English  literature  from  Sarah  Lawrence,  and  an  M.A.  in  Chinese  Literature  and  M.Phil.  in  Comparative  Literature  from  Columbia  University.

Look forward to seeing everyone,

results.description:
Photographer & Model Photoshoot Society Presents:

"Bikini and Lingerie Shoot w/Lily & Marissa - Aug. 16"


We're back this month with our two part August "Bikini and Lingerie" shoot. Last few weeks of summer and with the success of last months swimwear and outdoor boudoir look, we have two amazing models this months who won't disappoint.

About the Shoot:

We'll continue the summer swimwear theme and shoot glamour and pinup style looks. Weather permitting, we'll go outside and shoot some outdoor boudoir. (Disclaimer: The outdoor "woods" area is unkept and although there are many spots to shoot, shooting will be at the discretion of the organizers for safety and overall comfort for the photographers and model)

For new members: Please take the time to read the info below about how the Meetup is organized and how the shooting parameters are setup.

Cost: $80

(Cash preferred, Credit Cards/Paypal ok with $5 added for surcharge)

(Non-Commercial Release provided onsite or PDF version to email registered upon check-in.)

Models:

Lily Marie: MM#699957 

(Photo Credits: NandoPro)

(Photo sent by model for promotional purposes. All photo rights their respective owners.)

Marissa Centrella: MM#[masked]

(Photo sent by model for promotional purposes. All photo rights their respective owners.)

One-on-Ones: The models will be available for half hour one on one shoots after the Meetup. If you want to pre-book time before the shoot, send me a message.

NEW Shared One-on-Ones: We are also implementing a system that has been working for the past few Meetups. It's the sharing of a half hour one on one with a fellow photographer. It can be shared together for the whole half hour or 15 minutes each photographer. 

_______________________________________________________________________

About the Studio:

The studios is a beautiful 3,000 sq. ft., climate controlled,  fully functional studio. (Professional in-house lights, props, various seamless backdrops, actual commercial photography sets, kitchen, waiting room, meeting/presentation room, the works!) It's conveniently located to major highways and a 20-30 minute public transportation ride to and from NY.

About The Meetup Format:

We will keep the group small although we have the space to accommodate a big group. This keeps things from feeling rushed and overwhelming. Each photographer will have a set amount of time per look. This will allow you to  shoot as you would in an actual client shoot and not have to worry about the number of shots you are taking. (This proved to be ideal in our previous shoots as far as being able to get "the shot" and enough time to do so. Think of it as a mini one-on-one time with the model.) During the shoot we may opt to give a theme a direction to shoot for. As it would be for an actual client. (Ex: If the setup calls for a "cover shot" then it will give you a direction to aim for and to consider what equipment to use or what mood to capture.) No worries, bring what lens or lenses you have, you'll learn to use what you have for best results. We strive to bring forth real world conditions and parameters so there is a methodology to a setup or theme.

Check-in Procedure and Disclaimers:

Check-in - When you arrive, there will be a quick check-in. This will mostly be so you can read and adhere to the studio/group shoot guidelines and make payment for the shoot before we start. This will also let us send you the release forms in PDF format if we don't have physical copies available.

Releases - We will have one non-commercial release signed by the model through the studio only. (No additional releases will be signed.) If you need a commercial release signed, you can make arrangements with the model directly. Additional compensation for this is between the model and photographer.

Right to Refuse - We have the right to refuse a member's RSVP to the Meetup. It's a small community and models keep detailed info on photographers also. If we feel there is justifiable reason to refuse a RSVP, we will exercise that right.

Signups - Please signup when you know you will attend. If the signup passes the point to book another model and then we get no shows it's not fair to your fellow photographers who would be on a waiting list. It also puts the organizers in a tough spot, financially after booking an additional model to compensate for a bigger group. So, at the very least give us 3 days notice that you will not be able to attend or in case of no show, we will have to remove you from the group. When emergencies come up past the 3 days notice, followup with an email and we can make exceptions on a case by case basis. 

Model Cancellation - If a model cancels or a last minute model change occurs, you will have the option to cancel beforehand or not attend the Meetup on the day of, if it happens upon arrival to the Meetup.

Waitlist - When you are on a wait list, please be mindful as this is also considered a RSVP of availability. So, if we add another model or someone cancels within the 3 days before the shoot, your wait list status may upgrade to a "Yes". Please be on the lookout for updates on the Meetup page as Meetup sometimes takes longer to notify of a status change.

Updates - Updates will be made on this page up to the date of the Meetup or the night before. Emails will also be sent but Meetup emails are not always reliable to be sent to a receiver right away. (I've heard of emails arriving 3 hours later if at all.)

Postponements - Weather considerations will be made the night before a shoot or on the day of and the Meetup page will be updated as well as emails sent if a postponement occurs due to inclement weather or some other emergency. Lack of minimum RSVP to hold the event will also cause postponement of the shoot. The night before we would make the call wether to postpone so be on the look out for our email and Meetup page updates.

Any questions please email me at [masked]
results.name: Bikini and Lingerie Shoot w/Lily & Marissa - Aug. 16

I loves me some MOB. Their Mac and Cheese is everything. Now I get to try their Brunch/Lunch menu, and I couldn't be more excited.


It has a very unique atmosphere and is known for it's MOB's, which seem to be a fave among many who dine there. In fact, everyone has great things to say about all the items on their menu. And lucky for us, many of the choices seem to be prepared without all the soy additives that we sometimes like to stay away from.

Anytime I can start a meal with kale chips and a quinoa salad, it's a good time. But let's be real, I might go for the pancakes. We'll see how I feel. lol


Reservation's are always under my name. I reserved great outdoor seating for us, so pray there's no rain. haha. Also, if you're gunna pray, you might as well add something about it not being too hot either. Thanks!


As always, I'm down for hanging out afterward if anyone's interested.

Please do not RSVP unless you're sure you can attend. I like to keep the groups small, so if one person doesn't show up, others don't have the opportunity to join us. I know that sometimes things pop up that are beyond our control, but all I ask is that you be considerate and change your RSVP in a timely matter so that those on the waiting list have ample time to respond and attend. 

Thanks a bunch!

*There will be gluten-free options.

*I'm big on taking pictures. These events aren't for the camera shy ;)

Lets eat!

results.description:
SUNDAY, 8/16

1:30 PM

Havana Alma De Cuba, 94 Christopher St, New York, NY 10014 (b/t Bedford St & Bleecker St ) West Village

City Cinemas Angelika Film CenterAdd to Favorites

18 W. Houston St., New York, NY 10012 | [masked]

SHOWTIME: 3:55 PM

Plot Summary 

THE END OF THE TOUR tells the story of the five-day interview between Rolling Stone reporter (and novelist) David Lipsky (Jesse Eisenberg) and acclaimed novelist David Foster Wallace (Jason Segel), which took place right after the 1996 publication of Wallace's groundbreaking epic novel, Infinite Jest. As the days go on, a tenuous yet intense relationship seems to develop between journalist and subject. The two men bob and weave around each other, sharing laughs and also possibly revealing hidden frailties - but it's never clear how truthful they are being with each other. Ironically, the interview was never published, and five days of audio tapes were packed away in Lipsky's closet. The two men did not meet again. The film is based on Lipsky's critically acclaimed memoir about this unforgettable encounter, Although Of Course You End Up Becoming Yourself: A Road Trip with David Foster Wallace, written following Wallace's 2008 suicide.

Cast: Jesse Eisenberg , Jason Segel , Becky Ann Baker ,Anna Chlumsky , Joan Cusack , Mamie Gummer , Ron Livingston , Mickey Sumner

REVIEWS

Tampa Bay TimesSteve PersallAug 11,[masked]The End of the Tour asks viewers to lean in, listen well and be rewarded with an uncommonly intelligent and relatable movie experience.All this critic's reviewsRead full reviewWashington PostAnn HornadayAug 6,[masked]Improbably, The End of the Tour doesn’t just sustain the audience’s interest in Wallace and Lipsky’s exchanges, arguments and moments of bonding, but invites us to care deeply about the men.All this critic's reviewsRead full reviewChicago Sun-TimesRichard RoeperAug 6,[masked]It’s a brilliant slice of life.All this critic's reviewsRead full reviewGet a FiOS package that's made for streaming.Equip your apartment with FiOS QuantumSM 50/50 Mbps Internet, FiOS TV Local & your choice of HBO® or SHOWTIME® for 2 yrs. with No Annual Contract.Sponsored by Verizon FiOSNew York Magazine (Vulture)David EdelsteinJul 31,[masked]At times the movie’s small canvas feels momentous. They’ve found the inner tensions in people’s presentations of themselves in a way that’s positively Wallace-like.All this critic's reviewsRead full reviewLos Angeles TimesSheri LindenJul 30,[masked]James Ponsoldt's magnificent The End of the Tour gives us two guys talking, and the effect is breathtaking.All this critic's reviewsRead full reviewThe New York TimesA.O. ScottJul 30,[masked]It’s ultimately a movie — one of the most rigorous and thoughtful I’ve seen — about the ethical and existential traps our fame-crazed culture sets for the talented and the mediocre alike.All this critic's reviewsRead full reviewNew York Daily NewsJoe NeumaierJul 29,[masked]One of the best movies of the year.All this critic's reviewsRead full reviewNew York PostKyle SmithJul 29,[masked]The End of the Tour is a five-day bender of a talk — a film that illuminates like few others the singular pleasure of shared discovery of one another’s sensibility. In an unassuming way, it’s a glory.All this critic's reviewsRead full reviewEntertainment WeeklyChris NashawatyJul 30,[masked]Like "Almost Famous," Ponsoldt’s film gets at something deep and true about the journalist/subject dynamic and the phony intimacy and tiny betrayals implicit in it. It’s a profoundly moving story about a towering talent who seemed to feel too much and judge himself too harshly to stick around for long. What a shame.All this critic's reviewsRead full reviewThe A.V. ClubA.A. DowdJul 29,[masked]The result is less portrait of an artist than snapshot of a brief, meaningful encounter, shared between two men enjoying different stages of professional success. That one of these men happens to be a modern literary hero is almost, if not quite, incidental.All this critic's reviewsRead full reviewArizona RepublicBill GoodykoontzAug 6,[masked]There was a cry from Wallace fans when Segel was cast (some are still up in arms), but he’s terrific. So is Eisenberg, in an even more difficult role.All this critic's reviewsRead full reviewThe Hollywood ReporterDavid RooneyJan 25,[masked]Essentially, this is a film about existential emptiness, and yet it’s beautiful and alive, as filled with humor as it is with melancholy.

results.description:
This group is dedicated exclusively to novels. Please read the Novel Group Intro and FAQ before attending.  Be prepared to read back through previous chapters of a novel-in-progress before committing to this group.

HOW MEMBERS SUBMIT NOVEL SECTIONS:



Email your submission to [masked] 

SUBJECT: The Title of the group you're submitting to and your name. EXAMPLE: Cam's Novel Group December 8th, Spidercam
MESSAGE: Name, Title, Word Count, any additional info. EXAMPLE: Spidercam, Glory Chapter 2, 7,000 words. This is a rewrite.
Send to [masked]

Attach your document. RTF and DOC are preferred. Please, NO PDF's or DOCx. 


What to Expect: Nine days before the meeting you will receive an email from Meetup with links to download each story for critique from our Dropbox account. Click on the link and download the stories.

Please make sure your manuscript is properly formatted. See our Procedures, located under the Pages tab, for guidelines and an example, as well as advice for a constructive critique. Having manuscripts already formatted makes the critiquing process easier.


Most of the meeting will be spent critiquing work of group members. There is a structure in place to make sure the critiques are as helpful as possible for everyone involved, and that the writers leave with a clear idea of what to do with their stories next. You can find advice about how to give a critique here.

We'll also spend some time talking about writing, sharing news and information, and getting to know one another. It's always easier to take constructive criticism from someone you know, so the social element of the group is as important as the work itself!
results.name: Cam's Novel Group

results.description:
DNNY Meeting Announcement

Date: Sunday, August 16

Time: 2pm-4pm (Please arrive by 1:50pm. The meeting starts promptly at 2pm.)

Location: CAP 21 Studios, 18 West 18th St., (Between 5th Ave. & 6th Ave., NYC South Side of Street),6th Floor, Room 608.

Speaker: ELAINE KUBIAK

Topic: "SIMON PARKES: The Man and His Revelations” - Part 2

Program: (Live Event): Elaine will present the second half of the interview Q&A session of a three panel interview that Simon Parkes did for Yelm, Washington. The people in the audience are informed and enlightened and ask amazing questions that many DNNY members also had questions about. You can also read his bio and watch his videos on http://www.simonparkes.wix.com .
His story is quite frankly amazing. He comes from and illuminati family and from earliest childhood has been in frequent contact with Mantids, Draconis Reptilians and many other beings to the point that he was actually raised by them, particularly the Mantids, as well as by his earth Mom. She was actually supportive of him. When he was old enough to tell her about his experiences, she told him to “just draw me pictures and I’ll show them to my friends”, which he did and, consequently, Simon has an amazing collection of drawings by his own hand that are actually quite wonderful to see when he tells his story.
Simon’s mother worked for MI5 but was actually doing work from home (so she could be home to raise her son) for the NSA, typing documents that related to crashed UFO craft that had come down all over the Earth's surface and had then been retrieved by American special forces/recovery teams.

Her father, Simon’s grandfather, was a British diplomat and spy working for MI6, which work was closely associated with the CIA. During this time he was awarded the Order of the British empire (OBE) medal as well as the Commander of the British Empire (CBE) medal, however he turned down a Knighthood from the Queen. Simon's Grandfather was also a prominent Freemason and was Britain's appointed diplomat to the United Nations in the late 1950's and early 1960’s
Simon was elected to political office as council member for the town of Whitby, UK after he revealed his story, despite the attempts of the media to discredit him. He is currently taking a break from public office to attend to the work he does through his website and speaking engagements. Much of the work he is doing is to establish a worldwide net work of people who can help with the coming changes which he calls “ Connecting Consciousness”. He has an internet radio program by that name on Wolf Spirit Radio, which you can find on his website. He is likely to return to public office later this year.


Simon has assisted a growing number of people who have come forward from Illuminati families/bloodlines - where they have suffered torture and trauma, many from MILAB situations. Simon is able to re-integrate any alternate personalities that the individual may have, remove any Jinn/demonic possession and "de-activate" any suicide programs placed in the person.
On a lighter note Simon also does Soul readings, where in most cases is able to identify the individuals soul/star family background. This can help a person understand themselves better and also help them understand how they can be of help with the coming changes. A reasonable fee is charged for these services - Simon is offering a nearly unique service and places the highest value on client confidentiality - having helped people from many countries and from widely differing backgrounds, from college students to employees of the Rothschild's. Simon understands the critical nature of his deprogramming/healing/soul reading work and the support that his clients need.

Simon’s website is not yet taking appointments. He had got an amazing number of requests for sessions and then his website was attacked and his volunteer staff suffered scalar attacks. Most of his interviews are available on his website and provide a great deal of back up to David WIlcock, Corey Goode, David Icke, Tolec and many others.

Note: Elaine will provide an auxiliary cable that can accommodate 4 to 5 personal headphones for people who had difficulty hearing at her last presentation.

Please plan to attend what is bound to be one of the most interesting DNNY meetings to date and invite your interested friends to join us!

Meeting Details:

Admission: $10 per person. Children 12 and under are admitted for free.

R.S.V.P. Recommended for people attending the meeting for the first time. Please give us your full name, email address and phone number.per person. Send to: [masked] or for questions phone:[masked]

Note: No food or beverages are allowed in any rooms of the venue except bottled water that you may bring in. You can also purchase chilled bottled water at the Welcome Desk in the Lobby for $1.00.

No photos or recordings are permitted at meetings.

Note: Please silence your cell phones when entering the room.

Marjorie Eliot, who hosts her free Parlor Jazz set in her home at 555 Edgecombe Avenue every Sunday, is hosting her 23rd annual "Jazz At The Mansion" outdoor jazz performance on the lawn of the historic landmark Morris Jumel Mansion, Saturday August 15th & Sunday August 16, from 2pm - 6pm.


If you missed our meetup on December 14, 2014 at Ms. Eliot's home
(http://www.meetup.com/HarlemGo/events/219035123/), you should make one of the dates for this once-a-year event!

http://youtu.be/akE_YE_Mr3w?t=10s

Joining Ms. Eliot both days will be:
Saxophonists - Sedric Choukroun, Gerald Hayes, & Paul Ruffner
 Trumpets - Nicholas Mauro & Koichi Yoshihara
 Bass - Paul Beaudry
 Drums - Clay Herndon
 Clarinet - Lammott Cottman
 Flute - Vivian Ducat
 Poet - DFaye Anderson
 Musical Director, Piano & Vocals - Rudel Drears

<a>Our Meetup</a>

Everyone can sit where they want and arrive later than 2pm if they wish - our meetup will come together in the Mansion's kitchen area downstairs at the intermission of the concert (around 4pm) for a brief meet-and-greet. Sandwiches from Heights Tavern (heightstavernnyc.com) and refreshments will be served to HarlemGo members & the artist's & friends/family at in the Mansion's kitchen during the intermission (while supplies last).


<a>Special Note*</a> - Although the "Jazz At The Mansion" concert, food & refreshments are complimentary, please consider offering a donation to the house when the offering bucket goes around. What you care to offer is totally up to you, but let's return courtesy with consideration.

<a>As always, if you have any questions, running late, or need further directions for driving, street parking, etc. call/text Daniel at 774.275.3646. Thanks!</a>

Directions to the Morris-Jumel Mansion (65 Jumel Terrace)

By Train: Take the 'C' train (local) to 163 Street/Amsterdam Avenue. Walk to 160th street and Amsterdam, make a left and walk two blocks on 160th street to Jumel Terrace. Make a left on Jumel Terrace and the entrance to the mansion is in the middle of the block. The #1 train to 157th Street (Broadway) is an alternative (similar route).


By Bus: The M2, M3, M100, and M101 all have stops nearby.
results.how_to_find_us: On the Morris-Jumel Mansion grounds (160th Street & Jumel Terrace)
results.name: The 23rd Annual "Jazz At The Mansion" Concert w/Marjorie Eliot & Friends - 8/16

Lets' do it again and enjoy these beautiful pools while we can.  Just  a little over 3 WEEKS more  to go! Come take a break from the  "hot trails" and cool off with a refreshing swim at another local  gem in Park Ridge, NJ with Room to swim! (adult swims called if needed)


MEET JAY GLASER and (me)Susan BY THE ENTRANCE AS WE ARE HIS GUESTS OR GIVE HIS NAME WHEN YOU COME IN and look for the MEETUP SIGN INSIDE.  (will try to set up to the right of the diving boards if possible)

There are grassy areas and many free chairs available (first come basis) so you may want to bring your own lounge chairs, umbrellas and blankets. Food & Refreshments with healthy choices are also available to purchase. Option to eat at Peppercorns. 

Bring  something to share,  cards, etc and don't forget the sun protection and bugspray!


Stay for an hour or two or  stay til closing at 8 if you choose!  Admission is only $5.50 weekdays and $7.00 weekends for seniors, $10 for adults weekdays and $14 weekends the whole day and you do not have to be a resident!  Senior Residents are FREE. 

We only have til Labor Day, to enjoy these pools, so let's take advantage while the sun is shining!! Hope to see yah there. Let's "air out" those " tired dogs”!   

Directions From Rockland County: Take Rt 45(Chestnut Ridge Rd) toward Jersey to  Grand Ave.. 

Turn left onto Grand Ave..  

Turn right on Spring Valley Rd. at light. 

In a short distance turn left on Colony Ave. at Peppercorn Restaurant sign.

Pass Peppercorns restaurant immediately on your left and pool parking lot will come up shortly on your right.  LOOK FOR THE PARK RIDGE POOL SIGN ON THE ROCK.   Park and walk across the blue bridge to the entrance.

FOR additional DIRECTIONS GO TO: http://swim.isport.com/swimming-pools/us/new-jersey/park-ridge/park-ridge-municipal-pool-1018734   Enter your address and click on directions box. 

Inclement weather cancels.  Always check the day of an event for any changes.  See photos below for landmarks.  

Note diving boards and area to the right above (if not available look for meetup sign)

results.description:
Sometimes it's helpful to write in a group. So in this meeting we're coming together to just write. No critiques, no audiences (unless you want one), no pressure but that which you put on yourself.  Here's how it works:


Part 1: 

3:00- 3:45 we will write from a prompt provided by the organizer or one of the attending members.


Part 2:  

3:50 - 5:50 is dedicated time for free writing. Work on whatever you want.  We'd hope that work generated during these sessions will be submitted to any of the other Meetups or for broadcast on our podcast, Kaleidocast.


Please feel free to bring drinks or snacks. Arielle has power strips to plug in and space to write at both a table and on couches and chairs. Also, there are two cats, in case anyone has allergies.

See you there!

results.description:
"After five hundred years of prominence in Greek and Roman antiquity, Stoic ethics was pillaged by theology and effaced by evangelical and imperial Christianity." 

Thus began the decline of Stoicism according to Lawrence Becker in his book A New Stoicism. While the Stoic project ended in "a complete disaster" according to Becker, he notes that "a few [Stoics] are escaped to tell you" not only about its decline, but also how to rebuild Stoicism again. 

But with much of ancient Stoicism conflicting with modern culture, ethics, and science, how can we even begin to do so in a rigorous fashion that adheres to the ancient precept of living according to reason? We will study Becker's answer to this question as a capstone to our "Year of Modern Stoicism." Becker's book will be our focus throughout the rest of 2015.

To prepare for this meetup, please read all of Part One of Becker's A New Stoicism (Chapters 1-3; the "Commentary" on Chapter 3 is optional (as are all future chapter "commentaries"), but it contain a lot of interesting material, and you'd probably learn quite a bit from reading it).

Due to the theoretical bent of A New Stoicism, we will also dedicate some time to discussing everyday issues and problems from a Stoic perspective in order to balance Becker's theory with some practicality.

Since this may be a difficult read for some, there are some focus questions below to help guide your reading. Please attempt to answer them on your own. However, we'll also be discussing and answering these questions at the meetup. In addition, please highlight passages with concepts you found difficult, and we can discuss them at the meetup as well.

Focus questions:

Chapter 1

• What contributed to Stoicism's decline? 

Chapter 2

• Describe what the ancient Stoics meant by following nature and why moderns may reject it. 
• What are the major characteristics of Stoicism? And what would be missing from a modern Stoicism that was present in ancient Stoicism? 
• Why does the author say in the final paragraph that readers who are not Stoics will be more loyal to the ancient texts? 

Chapter 3

• What are the "peculiar doctrines" unique to Stoicism? 
• What are the main modern ethical theories that claim that "science" and ethics are divorced from each other? 
• Does Stoic ethics require a specialized kind of reasoning? Why or why not? 
• How does Becker's view of "human nature" differ from classical Stoicism? 
• Does Stoic ethics start with universals or particulars? How so? 
• What is the difference between practical reasoning and ethics according to Becker? 
• What can "X is good" mean? 
• What are the basic aims of Stoic training? 
• What is virtue according to Becker? 
• What is the frame of reference taken for Stoic ethics? 
• What is the aim of every rational agent according to Becker?
results.name: A New Stoicism I

results.description:
Med Tent is a safe space for people with mental health issues to hang out and be creative together! This Med Tent we will be exploring the surrealist drawing game Exquisite Corpse (all levels of drawing ability are welcome and wanted!)


Exquisite Corpse is a game where people take turns creating different parts of an image while having only minimal information about what their collaborators have already drawn.

Here's an example of an Exquisite Corpse generated image:

I am also hoping we can play the acting/improv game "Park Bench", though this will depend on how many people show up/are willing to act. 

There will be time to create flags/decorations for our ongoing project of creating non-graffiti street art for the streets of New York as well.

As always, you are perfectly free to not participate in these activities and just make the art you feel like making, or to just hang out and get to know people.

Hope to see you there!

-Josh K.
